title: Octave Sneeden
text:
Dr Jean Baptiste Octave Sneeden <a href="FRSE">FRSE</a> MIME MITE (1893–1973) was a 20th century Scottish engineer and author. As an author he is sometimes known as J. B. O. Sneeden.
Life.
He was born on the island of <a href="Mauritius">Mauritius</a> on 24 June 1893. He was the son of John Alexander Elvin Sneeden (b.1868) and his wife Maria Ravinia Georges (b.1872), and paternal grandson of John Townsend Sneeden of <a href="Annapolis">Annapolis</a> in <a href="Nova%20Scotia">Nova Scotia</a> and Maria Louise Georgina Sharrock of <a href="Port%20Louis%2C%20Mauritius">Port Louis, Mauritius</a>.
He studied Engineering Science at <a href="Glasgow%20University">Glasgow University</a> graduating BSc in 1917. He then immediately joined the staff of <a href="Walthamstow">Walthamstow</a> Technical College in north east <a href="London">London</a>. In 1920 he moved to the Royal Technical College in <a href="Glasgow">Glasgow</a> lecturing firstly on Heat Engines. He later became Head of Mechanical Engineering.
He received a doctorate (PhD) from Glasgow University in 1930. In 1932 he was elected a Fellow of the <a href="Royal%20Society%20of%20Edinburgh">Royal Society of Edinburgh</a>. His proposers were <a href="Herbert%20Stockdale">Herbert Stockdale</a>, <a href="Dugald%20McQuistan">Dugald McQuistan</a>, <a href="John%20McWhan">John McWhan</a> and <a href="David%20Ellis%20%28botanist%29">David Ellis</a>.
He died on 2 June 1976 at his home, 39 Kingshouse Avenue in <a href="Glasgow">Glasgow</a>.
Family.
He married Miss Gillard in <a href="Essex">Essex</a>.
